1118197252944744448.text: I think this skimmed over one of the benefits of SOA. 1108450783865913344.text:
Apple AirPods H1 chip (SOCs) has the processing power of an iPhone 4—in each ear!

Class 1 Bluetooth 5. H1 die size is ~12mm2. 

Parts:
H1
Cypress SoC
Maxim audio codec
Bosch BMA280 accelerometer
STM 3 axis accelerometer
STM regulator
TI data converter
Goertek MEMs microphonespic.twitter.com/XDZIKZaKoa

1120708532486144000.text: It seems like “we want to make the world a better place” is a bad way to really sell your idea. If you believe in the system, just make money.

1120708513184010240.text: Most successful businesses don’t change the world, but rather do something a tad better than competitors. A few more find some better way to organize resources coming in and out the door. Very few build something truly new. It’s all fine!

1120708452492378113.text: An interesting failure of modern capitalism and the entrepreneurship scene is failing to communicate that you don’t need start a business to change the world, but rather successful businesses change world generally as a side effect.

1120649717136990208.text: Also wondering out loud: when I got my student visa, it was tied to my major. No reason a loan could not be either. Using ISA as a way to calculate ROI is interesting, but admission criteria also gets in the way.https://twitter.com/lpolovets/status/1120478832954359808 …

1120115476695220226.text: I’m actually great at parties tyvm

1120113656455421952.text: “Happy X to those who celebrate” sound way more impersonal and measured than just saying “Happy X”. I know it’s supposed to signal thoughtfulness but to my ears, it just comes off as calculated and planned.

1120010643074113537.text: Yep. Every platform provider tries to fix this issue but requires a lot of handholding, user training, and tons of edge cases with non-standard forms, odd flows. IIRC, iCloud Keychain has hundreds of websites hardcoded for generating “correct” passwords.https://twitter.com/dsng/status/1120008505287749632?s=21 …

1120004417372209153.text: But still, password reuse and the various acct mgmt issues are so thorny that you can’t fault for people wanting to get rid of passwords forever. Biometrics? IMO, the right answer but obviously has its set of flaws like privacy implication and rotations.

1120004415522582528.text: There are ways to handle these like suspending phone numbers (they need to be inactive for 6mo in US before they can be reused IIRC) or verifying upon changing devices/sims.

1120004413144346624.text: Not that SMS is a panacea. Hijacking is an issue. But also people do change numbers. And more interestingly, phone numbers do change owners also. You need to be careful tying profiles to factors forever.https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2016/02/when-phone-verification-and-recycled-numbers-collide-lyft-leaks-user-data/ …

1120001991671988224.text: Good thread. I worked on authentication flows at Uber. Account takeovers via stolen passwords is a major headache which SMS 1FA hugely fixes. Fixing millions of people’s behavior (password reuse) is much harder than Verizon strengthening its practice.https://twitter.com/alexstamos/status/1119473074515185664 …

1108756328988790784.text: Maybe the credential store (culprit 1) is so cumbersome, that the growth oriented team (culprit 2) had to build something sketchy to meet their managers’ (culprit 3) KPIs!

1108758643779035138.text: Ok bye. Subscribe to my newsletter.

1108758418700025857.text: I don’t think FB will ever get there FWIW. A company whose product exists as a function of the data you wished you didn’t share won’t respect your data.

1108758416716120066.text: But making sure you can have secure systems that can be used (think entire prod lifecycle) easily and making people understand that PII is as much of an liability as it’s an asset, esp at cos like FB, is very hard.

1108757495495999490.text: Joking aside, it’s fun and easy to blame individual engineers, but as cliche as it sounds, this stuff is organizational issues. Nothing about storing passwords or building ACLs is rocket science.

1108756706429992960.text: If you’ve logged into Uber in the past 3 years, please forward me your bug reports so I can ignore them.

1108756327407513602.text: I can see how the first one can happen; a team builds a new product really fast (grow!!!) and doesn’t bother to use proper solutions to store credentials. Whose fault is it?

1108756324333092865.text: It’s one thing to store passwords in plaintext (bad!), it is another thing to have that many people have access to a database that have them (bad!)

1108755198737084416.text: How does Facebook, the supposedly one of the more capable engineering firms, have such shoddy security *and* such shoddy internal controls?

1108652190565052416.text: Multiple people DM'ed me to say they know vocal alt-right people at their respective tech firms.https://twitter.com/can/status/1108493636361162754 …

1108513721779974144.text: Obviously someone more seasoned in these matters said this a long time agohttps://twitter.com/sarahjeong/status/1108477234686263296 …

1108497783160492032.text: Again, I am quite unqualified to comment on these matters.  The thread I was pulling was Google's "memogate" and remembering how I've *cough*heard*cough* about spies in certain companies.

1108497781340160000.text: It is one thing to protect your IP and keep data private internally against foreign spies, but when you realize there are people who are affiliated with Nazis on their free time, what do you?

1108496930286505986.text: Not a lawyer, but in CA (and NY) political affiliation is illegal to discriminate against. Could you even fire someone for being a white supremacist? Seems like you should be able to, but again, these decisions are tough.

1108496928025788416.text: It is wishful to think that unless we have a legal framework and a shared understanding that white supremacy is an evil force, this will disappear from the web. We had Obama come out and say "We will destroy ISIS".

1108493640429641731.text: Not saying the reason white supremacy isn't being obliterated from the web is because some people at Google want to keep them online. But rather, white supremacy is a cultural phenomenon that we need to attack on all fronts. I don't think we came to terms with it fully yet

1108493637854396416.text: For example, there are definitely foreign spies working at your favorite tech firm. It's a fact of life; and it's one that you can limit the damage of by strong internal controls.

1108493636361162754.text: What's the over/under that there are multiple white nationalists working at Twitter/Google/Facebook? They employ more than 130K people in total. I am not a statistician, but it does seem possible. Definitely more likely than ISIS spies.https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/ryanhatesthis/will-silicon-valley-treat-white-nationalism-as-terrorism …

1108465650962497543.text: This is true regardless of whether or not Lyft or Uber makes money. GM and Lyft aren’t in the same business.

1107771546658111488.text: How does anyone write anything for online, where you have to assume everyone is going to read everything you write in bad faith? I am so tired of wrapping every sentence in qualifiers and building the context for every statement. This could be 100 words, yet I am at 1500.

1107768323666784257.text: I did not know my Twitter brand was this strong.

1107366282809225216.text: I just reminded myself of the Great JavaScript Semicolon Wars of 2011.

1023650590490914816.text: In order to keep my Twitter ephemeral, I delete all my tweets every 2-3 weeks and unfollow everyone every few months. And when I slowly follow people back, they get sort of upset I unfollowed. The solution is to stop caring who follows you or not on here.

1107304982758543361.text: Just because I don’t code anymore doesn’t mean I’m going to pollute the namespace.

2) These are the numbers Facebook can detect. Historically, FB has been known to update such estimates, generally up.https://twitter.com/fbnewsroom/status/1107117981358682112 …

1107024838110138368.text: Late night döner with ayran on the side. Love French food.

1106839772545384449.text: I am still gathering my thoughts on Apple vs Spotify but calling someone else’s profit margin a tax is an interesting turn of phrase. “Can you believe it?! They are taxing us!”

1106853756937867264.text: Or maybe I just don’t get it.

1106853469657448448.text: They really don’t make @farmersonly commercials like they used to.https://youtu.be/R3gjU8lGRi8

1106839780652994560.text: This is obviously more of an American reaction. But the antagonistic view of the government here in US is odd. I’m not saying taxes are an unadulterated good, but they aren’t bad. It’s how we fund the government that keeps you safe and sound.

1106839777935048704.text: A more tangential point is how “tax” is used as a negative term in these discussions. Not cool!

1106839776529973248.text: Does Apple truly not have competition? Really depends on your market definition in the end. Can Apple not set the rules of its walled garden? I generally see the world of business thru lens of competition but even for me, lack of competition case seems week.

1106839775233953792.text: Where the “tax” analogy works is when you don’t have competition. You just cannot pay. Obvi you cant not pay taxes to the G man not due to lack of competition (barring UAE, Singapore examples) but obligation is obligation.

1106839774046883841.text: Part of me is bothered by the framing. Every business puts a profit margin on the goods and services it provides. And it’s through that profit that business exists. How is that nefarious?

1106478083903762432.text: Now, if I had the ability to have a French sounding robot (which discloses it is a robot) make a reservation for me, would that be OK or misleading? Or would a restaurant that refuses reservations in non-native French would also not take a reservation from a robot anyway?

1106478082708389888.text: Context is that there are restaurants near where I live that, casually, prefer locals over students. And having to have a reservation in French is an imperfect way to do so. I speak enough French to survive in that setting, but my accent obviously gives it away.

1106478081445908481.text: Idly wondering about the ethics of using Google Duplex to make reservations at a French restaurant that only have French staff. Would that be kosher?
